Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2010 03:14PM Kelley41 wrote: Thank you for sharing...it is readable and great information!
Posts.Title: LYMPHEDEMA GETS SOME MEDIA ATTENTION! LindaLou53 SleeveNinja

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2011 02:20PM Kelley41 wrote: I had a lumpectomy at one hospital and the lab said HER +,  ended up have a double mastecomy at another hospital and that lab said HER borderline +.  It was then they sent it out for the FISH test and it came back that I was HER - ....making me a Triple Negative.  It was my understanding that path reports are subjective to the person reading them and that the FISH test is very expensive but very accurate and not subjective.  Thank god I ended up having the second surgery or they would of been treating me with Herceptin which would of not helped me.  I ended up getting a few opinions.
Posts.Title: Conflicting path reports SunCrystal SunCrystal

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2010 08:11PM Kelley41 wrote: I actually found more support with my co-workers/friends/neighbors.  My family doesnt live close and they were there in the beginning for me over the phone and sending flowers but that was about it.  My parents dont like to talk about "it" and I have come to the  conclusion that is thier way to deal....if they dont talk about it, then it isnt happening.  I had my last chemo treatment this month and actually spoke to my mother on that day and all she could talk about was her dog.  Two weeks later, she asked when  my last treatment was and I told her I already had it and that was the end of the conversation.  I would lie if I said it didnt botter me but the most important thing is to surround yourself with positive and supportive people.  This site will be a good source of information for you - good luck!
Posts.Title: Surgery Tommorow : No family support Ondagrow Renrel

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2010 06:11PM Kelley41 wrote: Sorry that I cant help you with a name of a Doctor - I am in Rochester NY.  My HER2 status was an issue also.  I first had a lumpectomy and thats when they discovered it was Cancer.  That hospital said I was HER2 +.  I then decided to have a double mastecomy.  This second Hospital said I was HER2 borderline.  Because of the difference, they sent it out for a FISH test to get an "accurate" result and that came back HER2 -.  If I did not have the double mastecomy, they would have been treating me with Herceptin which would of been the wrong drug!  I went for a second opinion and had them take another look at everything.  The second place I went to is where I ended up.  They are a large treatment center and have a section just for Breast Cancer and the pathologists look just at breast cancer samples.  It was told to me that looking at the samples may vary from one person to the next.  I hope you are able to find the best care!
Posts.Title: Can't determine Her2 status jeanne11 jeanne11

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2010 02:57AM Kelley41 wrote: I was told that when the HER2 status is borderline, a FISH test MUST be done to determine the status.  Are there any Breast Cancer support groups in your area that you can go and talk to others and maybe get some names of good Doctors in your area or even close by?  I hope you get the answers you need and that you deserve!
Posts.Title: Can't determine Her2 status jeanne11 jeanne11

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2010 07:03AM Kelley41 wrote: Went to the new massage therapist yesterday and I feel like a new person!  After the 9 visits (at $360.00 for copays) I recieved more information and 45 minutes of massage vs. the 5 - 10 I was recieving at the other place.  This new place has a RN on site who measured me before and after the massage and fitted me with a sleeve and gaunlet on site and I went home with both yesterday.  I felt like a kid on Christmas morning.  The other place was telling me about 3 more weeks for my sleeve and gaunlet to come in - this was after 5 weeks already being wrapped like the Michelan Man.  I sure wish I had done my homework before going for treatments because I learned the hard way...I was worried about insurance because of the switch of services and this new place gave me the response of "off the record, you have been jerked around so much - we have never seen such a thing - that we would like to over accomadate you.  Dont worry about the insurance, we will take care of it for you...."  WOW
Posts.Title: Lymphedema and Insurance Kelley41 EstherMSKCC

Posts.Content: Kelley41 wrote: This may of already been covered but I looked and could not find the topic....Newly diagnosed with Lymphedema and I am into week four of bandaging and am awaiting my sleeve.  I am being told that the hold up with my sleeve is that the insurance company is dragging its feet.  I told my OT that I would pay out of pocket because I am tired of waiting and being bandaged like the Michilan Man.  I was also told that my insurance, which is a good one, will only pay half for my sleeve and gaunlet.   I am so tired of paying $40.00 twice a week for OT when I feel like all they do is 5 minutes of massage and rebandage me!  I already had to pay for all of my bandages because I was told my insurance would not cover it - I already have paid $96.00 for my badages and have already gone to 8 OT sessions @ $40.00 each time.  I want to get a shirt made that says.....If the cancer doesn't kill me, the co-pays will!  Dx 1/10/2010, IDC, <1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Lymphedema and Insurance Kelley41 EstherMSKCC

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2011 09:52AM Kelley41 wrote: Nancy - Its almost like you read my mind....I feel the same way.  I had a double mastecomy and love not having to wear a bra!!!!!  I told my plastic surgeon that I wanted a break from visiting Doctors so I pushed back my next appt with him.  My next appt with him is in April and I am sure that I will have to make some decision about my next step - not sure what to do but I know that I love not having to put a bra on!!!!!!
